thread.title: Emmitt Smith's return to the Swamp special moment for Gators and their coach
thread.title_full: Emmitt Smith's return to the Swamp special moment for Gators and their coach

author: Edgar Thompson
title: Emmitt Smith's return to the Swamp special moment for Gators and their coach
text:
Emmitt Smith's return to the Swamp special moment for Gators and their coach bobby coker / orlando sentinel 
Emmitt Smith, University of Florida college football (UF) published on 8/30/2012 
Emmitt Smith, University of Florida college football (UF) published on 8/30/2012 (bobby coker / orlando sentinel) Edgar Thompson Contact Reporter Orlando Sentinel Smith ran for 3,928 yards in three seasons at Florida 
Florida coach Jim McElwain had things under control. Either way, he would not have gotten in the way of the man arguing with an official farther down the sideline. 
Emmitt Smith was emotionally into Saturday night’s 38-10 win against Ole Miss. Meanwhile, McElwain was into having Smith on the sideline, back with the Gators. 
“Shoot guys, I was like a kid in a candy store,” McElwain said. “I actually got to shake Emmitt Smith’s hand, that was pretty neat, you know. That means a lot.” 
Smith’s rare appearance in Gainesville was a ringing endorsement of the direction of Florida football under McElwain. 
Smith’s frustration boiled over when quarterback Jeff Driskel threw three interceptions during last September’s blowout loss at Alabama. Smith tweeted, "put Driskel on the bench please, I've seen enough.” 
Smith, who rushed for 224 yards against the Crimson Tide in his first start at Florida, later apologized. But it was clear one of the program’s best players and NFL’s all-time leading rusher wanted change. 
Smith’s appearance last Saturday left effusive defensive end Alex McCalister speechless. 
“I was getting dressed and I just had happened to turn right and Emmitt Smith is sitting down right there,” McCalister recalled. “My heart dropped for a second. I was like, ‘Dawg, Emmitt Smith is really right here in our locker room just chillin’.” 
Tailback Kelvin Taylor said it was special to get advice and feedback from a player who set the standard at Florida. 
“It was pretty cool just him out there on the sideline telling me when I made a good cut,” Taylor said. “It doesn’t really get no better than that." 
McElwain agreed. 
“I was a little giddy,” he said. “I had a chance to meet one of the best ever at his position. Never would have thought that would happen.” 
Email Edgar Thompson at egthompson@orlandosentinel.com . Read the Swamp Things blog at www.orlandosentinel.com/swampthings . Follow our UF coverage on Twitter @osgators .
